class.name: Sandbox
class.brief_description: Sandbox is designed to run programs in a controlled environment, providing a safe way to execute code with restricted access to the Godot engine's API and resources.
class.description: The Sandbox class is designed to run ELFScript resources or byte arrays from unknown sources, encapsulating them in a controlled environment. It provides a way to execute code with restricted access to the Godot engine's API and resources.

method.name: FromBuffer
method.description: Creates a new Sandbox instance from a PackedByteArray buffer containing the binary data of an ELF program. This is useful for loading ELF programs dynamically at runtime. Eg. from a downloaded file.

method.name: FromProgram
method.description: Creates a new Sandbox instance from an ELF resource. [codeblocks] [gdscript] var sandbox = Sandbox.FromProgram(Sandbox_TestTest) [/gdscript] [/codeblocks]

method.name: add_allowed_object
method.description: Adds an Object instance to the list of allowed objects in the Sandbox. Allowed objects can be referred to, accessed and potentially manipulated by the sandboxed program.

method.name: address_of
method.description: Returns the address of a symbol in the sandboxed program. This can be used to get the memory address of functions or variables defined in the ELF program.

method.name: assault
method.description: Performs a stress test on the sandboxed program by executing a specified test function multiple times. For internal testing only.

method.name: clear_allowed_objects
method.description: Clears the list of allowed objects in the Sandbox. After calling this method, no objects will be accessible to the sandboxed program until new ones are added.

method.name: clear_hotspots
method.description: Clears the list of hotspots measured by profiling.

method.name: download_program
method.description: Downloads a program from a GitHub release page and returns its binary content as a PackedByteArray. This is a blocking operation that will wait until the download is complete.

method.name: emit_binary_translation
method.description: Generates a binary translation of the sandboxed program as textual C code. This C source file can then be compiled into a shared library for execution. Loading the resulting shared library will allow the sandboxed program to run closer to native performance. If `ignore_instruction_limit` is true, the instruction limit will not be enforced, improving performance. Having an execution limit is only really recommended while building programs, as the worst case scenario is that the program or game appears to hang, which is not a security issue in most cases. If `automatic_nbit_address_space` is true, the translation will automatically use an n-bit (masked) address space, which can greatly improve performance for certain programs. It is however, somewhat experimental and may not work with all programs.

method.name: generate_api
method.description: Generates an API header file for the sandboxed program in the specified language. This header file contains function declarations and type definitions for the sandboxed program's API. It can be used to interact with the entire/full Godot API from the sandboxed program.

method.name: get
method.description: Retrieves the value of a property by its name from the Sandbox.

method.name: get_current_instruction
method.description: Returns the current instruction being executed in the sandboxed program. This can be useful for debugging or profiling purposes.

method.name: get_floating_point_registers
method.description: Returns an Array of floating-point registers used by the sandboxed program. This can be useful for inspecting the state of floating-point computations.

method.name: get_general_registers
method.description: Returns an Array of general-purpose registers used by the sandboxed program. This can be useful for inspecting the state of the program's execution.

method.name: get_hotspots
method.description: Returns an Array of hotspots used for profiling. Hotspots are functions or code segments that are frequently executed in the sandboxed program.

method.name: get_property_list
method.description: Returns a list of all properties available in the Sandbox, including properties that are defined in the sandboxed program (by the program).

method.name: has_function
method.description: Checks if the sandboxed program has a function with the specified name. This can be used to verify the existence of functions before attempting to call them.

method.name: has_program_loaded
method.description: Checks if the sandboxed program has been successfully loaded. This is useful to ensure that the program is ready for execution before making any calls.

method.name: is_allowed_class
method.description: Checks if a class with the specified name is allowed in the Sandbox. This is used to restrict access to certain classes for security or performance reasons.

method.name: is_allowed_method
method.description: Checks if a method is allowed to be called on the specified Object instance. This is used to enforce restrictions on method calls in the sandboxed program.

method.name: is_allowed_object
method.description: Checks if an Object instance is allowed to be accessed in the Sandbox. This is used to restrict access to certain objects for security or performance reasons.

method.name: is_allowed_property
method.description: Checks if a property is allowed to be accessed or set on the specified Object instance. This is used to enforce restrictions on property access in the sandboxed program.

method.name: is_allowed_resource
method.description: Checks if a resource with the specified name is allowed in the Sandbox. This is used to restrict access to certain resources for security or performance reasons.

method.name: load_binary_translation
method.description: Loads a binary translation of the sandboxed program from a shared library. This allows the sandboxed program to run closer to native performance by executing pre-compiled code.

method.name: load_buffer
method.description: Loads a sandboxed program from a PackedByteArray buffer containing the binary data of an ELF program.

method.name: lookup_address
method.description: Looks up the name of a symbol at a specific memory address in the sandboxed program. This can be useful for debugging or profiling purposes to identify which function or variable is located at a given address.

method.name: make_resumable
method.description: Makes the sandboxed program resumable, allowing it to be paused and resumed later. Does not work properly right now. Do not use.

method.name: remove_allowed_object
method.description: Removes an Object from the list of allowed objects in the Sandbox. After calling this method, the specified object will no longer be accessible to the sandboxed program.

method.name: reset
method.description: Resets the Sandbox to its initial state. If `unload` is true, it will also unload the currently loaded program, clearing all state.

method.name: restrictive_callback_function
method.description: A restrictive callback function that can be used to enforce restrictions on method calls in the Sandbox. This function can be set as a callback to restrict access to certain methods or properties.

method.name: resume
method.description: Resumes the execution of the sandboxed program after it has been paused. Does not work properly right now. Do not use.

method.name: set
method.description: Sets the value of a property by its name in the Sandbox. This can be used to modify properties of the sandboxed program or its environment.

method.name: set_argument_registers
method.description: Sets the argument registers for the sandboxed program. This allows you to specify the initial values of registers that will be used when the program starts executing.

method.name: set_class_allowed_callback
method.description:
Sets a callback that determines whether a class may be instantiated in the Sandbox. This can be used to restrict access to certain classes for security reasons.
Please note that the sandboxed program is always allowed to instantiate Variant types.

method.name: set_method_allowed_callback
method.description: Sets a callback that determines whether a method is allowed to be called on an Object instance in the Sandbox. This can be used to enforce restrictions on method calls in the sandboxed program.

method.name: set_object_allowed_callback
method.description: Sets a callback that determines whether an Object instance is allowed to be accessed in the Sandbox. This can be used to restrict access to certain objects for security or performance reasons.

method.name: set_property_allowed_callback
method.description: Sets a callback that determines whether a property is allowed to be accessed or set on an Object instance in the Sandbox. This can be used to enforce restrictions on property access in the sandboxed program.

method.name: set_redirect_stdout
method.description: Sets a callback to redirect the standard output (stdout) of the sandboxed program. This allows you to capture and process output generated by the program, such as print statements.

method.name: set_resource_allowed_callback
method.description: Sets a callback that determines whether a resource is allowed in the Sandbox. This can be used to restrict access to certain resources for security reasons.

method.name: try_compile_binary_translation
method.description: Attempts to generate and then compile a binary translation of the sandboxed program into a shared library. This allows the sandboxed program to run closer to native performance by executing pre-compiled code. If the compilation is successful, the shared library will be loaded automatically on platforms that support loading shared libraries.

method.name: vmcall
method.description: Calls a function in the sandboxed program with the provided arguments. This is used to make function calls defined in the ELF program from the Godot engine. Functions in the Sandbox always return a Variant. The first argument is the string name of the function to call, and subsequent arguments are passed as parameters to that function. If the function does not exist, an error will be thrown. Calling a function with the wrong arguments can lead to undefined behavior, so it is important to ensure that the function signature matches the arguments being passed. If this is undesirable please have a look at [code skip-lint]vmcallv()[/code] which uses Variant for all arguments and is more resistant to mistakes, but also less performant. [codeblocks] [gdscript] var sandbox = Sandbox.new() sandbox.set_program(Sandbox_TestTest) sandbox.vmcall("my_function", 123, "hello", [4.0, 5.0, 6.0]) [/gdscript] [/codeblocks] In order for the above function call to work, the sandboxed program must have a function that expects those exact arguments. C++ example: [codeblocks] [gdscript] Variant my_function(int a, String b, Array c) { print("my_function called with args: ", a, ", ", b, ", ", c) return c[0] + c[1] + c[2]; } [/gdscript] [/codeblocks]

method.name: vmcallable
method.description: Creates a Callable that can be used to later make a function call into the sandbox. The args parameter allows you to specify the pre-defined arguments that will be passed to the function when it is called. Regular callable arguments will then be appended when the callable is invoked. Eg. [code][1, 2, 3][/code] will call the function with the arguments 1, 2, 3, and after that any arguments passed to the callable will be appended to the end of the argument list.

method.name: vmcallable_address
method.description: Creates a callable object that can be used to later call a function at a specific memory address in the sandboxed program. Works the same way as [code skip-lint]vmcallable()[/code], but instead of a function name, it takes any executable address.

method.name: vmcallv
method.description: Calls a function in the sandboxed program with the provided arguments, similar to vmcall, but uses Variants for all arguments. This is more resistant to mistakes, as it does not require knowing argument types in advance, but is less performant than vmcall. The first argument is the string name of the function to call, and subsequent arguments are passed as Variants to that function. If the function does not exist, an error will be thrown. Note that the function inside the sandboxed program must also take each argument as a Variant, otherwise it will not work correctly. For maximum flexibility, one could use vmcallv with an Array as the first argument, which lets you iterate the arguments inside the function.

members.member: The maximum number of heap allocations allowed inside the sandbox.

The maximum number of instructions that can be executed in a single function call. If this limit is reached, the current function call will be terminated to prevent infinite loops or excessive resource consumption.
The maximum amount of memory (in megabytes) that the sandboxed program can use.
The total accumulated time spent on initializing all sandboxes.
The total number of function calls made to this sandbox.
The total number of exceptions thrown by the sandbox.
The total number of execution timeouts that have occurred in the sandbox.
The total number of function calls made across all sandboxes.
The total number of exceptions thrown across all sandboxes.
The total number of execution timeouts that have occurred across all sandboxes.
The total number of sandbox instances currently active.
The total number of heap allocations made in the sandbox.
The total number of heap chunks currently allocated by the sandbox.
The total number of heap deallocations made in the sandbox.
The current amount of memory (in bytes) used by the heap in the sandbox.

Enables or disables precise simulation mode for the sandboxed program. When enabled, the program will use a more accurate simulation, producing better backtraces and profiling data, but at the cost of performance.
Enables or disables profiling for the sandboxed program. When enabled, the sandbox will collect profiling data about function calls and execution times.

The ELFScript program that is currently loaded in the Sandbox. This is the program that will be executed when the sandbox is run and when functions are called.
[codeblocks] [gdscript] var sandbox = Sandbox.new() sandbox.set_program(Sandbox_TestTest) [/gdscript] [/codeblocks]
The maximum number of object references that can be held in the sandboxed program.
Enables or disables restrictions on the sandboxed program. When enabled, the program will have limited access to the Godot engine's API and resources.
Enables or disables the use of unboxed arguments for function calls. When enabled, function arguments will be passed as their real types instead of Variants, which improves performance.
